Why is Venus so hot?

The planet’s thick CO2-filled atmosphere is great at trapping heat. This creates a runaway greenhouse effect that makes Venus roughly 700°F (389°C) hotter than it would be otherwise. 
@NASAJPL
's Dr. Amy Hofmann gives us the details: https://go.nasa.gov/42FxR4v
In collaboration with @GoogleArts, @NASAGoddard scientist Dr. Heather Graham sits down with @Astro_Kobi to discuss how we find answers to the age-old question: Is there life beyond Earth?

Why is Venus so hot?

The planet’s thick CO2-filled atmosphere is great at trapping heat. This creates a runaway greenhouse effect that makes Venus roughly 700°F (389°C) hotter than it would be otherwise. @NASAJPL's Dr. Amy Hofmann gives us the details: https://go.nasa.gov/42FxR4v

Join us at 7:30am ET (1130 UTC) on June 15 for another spacewalk! @NASA_Astronauts Steve Bowen and @Astro_Woody will install another roll-out solar array on the @Space_Station, scheduled to start at 8:55am ET (1255 UTC).

Join us for a "guided tour" of our "Eyes on Asteroids" real-time visualization app. Learn how to use the tool and explore the 28,000 known asteroids and comets in our cosmic neighborhood.

#MissionToPsyche is on track for launch in October 2023!

An independent review board found JPL’s response to address factors contributing to the mission’s 2022 launch delay has been "world class."

LIVE: Tune in as we review next steps for the Psyche mission, set to launch no earlier than Oct. 2023. The spacecraft will study a metal-rich asteroid of the same name that may be the partial core of a building block of rocky planets in our solar system.

You're looking at 45,000+ galaxies.

This image was taken as part of the JWST Advanced Deep Extragalactic Survey (JADES) — a massive science program that’s revolutionizing what we know about galaxies in the early universe: https://go.nasa.gov/3CdLq0s

I just reached a milestone only surpassed by Opportunity: 30 km on Mars   

I've explored so much in my 10-plus-year trek through Gale Crater, but there are many more rocks to sample and analyze! Retrace my tracks with this interactive map: http://go.nasa.gov/3EtmSCi

The diversity of our NASA team is what brings different perspectives to our missions, and we celebrate and share their stories. To protect our people from personal attacks, we have decided to limit comments on this post.

This month and every month, we recognize the achievements and contributions of our Asian American, Native Hawaiian, and Pacific Islander workforce.

LIVE: Experts at @NASA_Johnson are discussing our upcoming spacewalks, scheduled for June 9 and June 15, to set up new solar arrays outside the @Space_Station.

We're taking questions from media and the public—share your spacewalk Qs with #AskNASA.

Hurricane season in the Atlantic begins today. Our unique perspective from space allows us to study storms and their evolution, providing data to support forecasting and disaster responses: https://go.nasa.gov/3fYNZYE

Join us and @LibraryCongress as U.S. Poet Laureate Ada Limón reveals her poem for the @EuropaClipper mission. The poem will be engraved on the spacecraft, and travel 1.8 billion miles (2.89 billion kilometers) to an icy moon of Jupiter. 

Tune in: https://bit.ly/42eJZJO

NOW: We're holding a public meeting of our independent study team for categorizing and evaluating data of unidentified anomalous phenomena, or UAP. More info on today's meeting: https://go.nasa.gov/3nVqp7g

Welcome back to Earth! It's been an incredible journey for the all-private astronaut crew of #Ax2. They've conducted vital scientific experiments and brought the wonders of space closer to us all. Congratulations to @SpaceX and @Axiom_Space for another successful mission!

Hey, you: Get a load of this cloud! High-altitude ice clouds (like this one) can help regulate Earth's temperature by reflecting energy from the Sun.

A new 
@NASAEarth
 mission called PoISIR aims to study them in greater detail to improve climate forecasts. https://go.nasa.gov/3IAfgjj
